citations.narrative:
* The Contingency plan was incomplete. The plan did not address all possible contingents for the facility. An incomplete
contingency plan could affect the well-being of the animals.
A completed contingency plan addressing all possible contingents for the facility must be installed, therefore protecting
the well-being of the animals.

* Upon request there was no written exercise plan. This indicates the animals may not be receiving required exercise.
For appropriate exercise and the dogs well-being, a written exercise plan must be developed and available upon request
concerning the 11 adult dogs.

* The Program of Veterinary Care did not address vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases and a sampling and
treatment of parasites and other pest in accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian. (A.V.) This
could affect the health and increase the disease potential for the 11 adult dogs.
To minimize the disease hazards and for the animals health and well-being, a completed Program of Veterinary Care
must be develop by the A.V. addressing the needs of this Section and implemented.
This is a (1st) Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within (2 ) more inspection(s) or by (3rd of May-60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection)
or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule
your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning. 
*  The Contingency plan was incomplete.  The plan did not address all possible contingents for the facility.  An incomplete 
contingency plan could affect the well-being of the animals. 
A completed contingency plan addressing all possible contingents for the facility must be installed, therefore protecting 
the well-being of the animals. 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
* Upon request there was no written exercise plan.  This indicates the animals may not be receiving required exercise.   
For appropriate exercise and the dogs well-being, a written exercise plan must be developed and available upon request 
concerning the 11 adult dogs. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* The Program of Veterinary Care did not address vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases and a sampling and 
treatment of parasites and other pest in accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian. (A.V.)  This 
could affect the health and increase the disease potential for the 11 adult dogs.

To minimize the disease hazards and for the animals health and well-being, a completed Program of Veterinary Care 
must be develop by the A.V. addressing the needs of this Section and implemented. 
 
This is a (1st) Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within (2 ) more inspection(s) or by (3rd of May-60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection) 
or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule 
your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
